results.title: Crustaceans: lobsters, barnacles, shrimps and their relative
results.creator_credit: William A. Anderson and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: The appearances, habitat and behaviour of the most important types of Crustaceans are shown. The distinguishing features of the five tuypes are illustrated with close-up views of the animals in their natural environment. Designed for high school classes in biology and zoology.

results.title: Crush
results.creator_credit: Alison MacLean, Bridget Ikin and Hibiscus Films
results.brief_description: Alison Maclean’s (“Kitchen sink”, “Jesus’ son”) debut feature is a macabre psychological study of obsession, sexual jealousy and female friendships. Marcia Gay Harden stars as the brazen and destructive Lane, a classic femme fatale archetype who finds herself stuck in the sleepy New Zealand town of Rotorua after she and her girlfriend Christina (Donogh Rees) are involved in a near fatal car accident. Lane walks away from the crash site unharmed, leaving her friend for dead and lands on the doorstep of the shy and tomboyish Angela (Caitlin Bossley) and her novelist father Colin (William Zappa). The awkward teen soon develops a crush on the more sexually confident Lane, who in turn makes a play for Angela’s father, leaving the abandoned girl devastated and thirsty for revenge. Maclean uses the shifting power plays as an astute metaphor for New Zealand’s own confused relationship to cultural identity, shrewdly casting an American as the self assured and opportunistic outsider, while setting the film in the mainly Maori community of Rotorua. Cast also includes Peter Smith and Jon Brazier.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Alison MacLean, Bridget Ikin and Hibiscus Films

results.title: Crucifixion: theme and variations
results.creator_credit: George Jacobson, J.H. Lenauer, Mavis Lyons and Filmmakers
results.brief_description: Interpretation by three Flemish artists, of the theme of the Crucifixion from the original paintings in the Johnson Collection at the Philadelphia Museum of Art. The following are studied: “Christ carrying the Cross” by the Master of the Turin Adoration (1490-1510); “Christ on the Cross and the Virgin and St. John” by Roger van der Weyden (1399-1464); and “Pieta” by Gerard David (1460-1523). Commentary by Murvyn Vye.
results.creator_credit_for_label: George Jacobson, J.H. Lenauer, Mavis Lyons and Filmmakers

results.title: Crow boy (K)
results.creator_credit: Cynthia Freitag and Weston Woods Studios
results.brief_description: A shy boy attending a village school in Japan withdraws into a world of his own until a kind and wise teacher draws him out and his classmates discover his special talent. Based on the book of the same title by Taro Yashima.

results.title: Crossroads of life
results.creator_credit: Henri Storck and United Nations. Dept. of Public Information
results.brief_description: Hihglights several cases of children with serious problems, who are helped to understand their needs and become healthier people. After becoming delinquent, they are treated in a children’s institution. Scenes show therapeutic work to help them relieve aggressive feelings. International cooperation to improve methods of prevention, observation and treatment of delinquency is urged.

results.title: Crossbanding and jointing veneers
results.creator_credit: K. Baron Hartley and Topical Film Company
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Basic woodwork”.
Both sides of the wood are veneered to prevent warping. The method of making this is demonstrated through an example of a door made of laminated wood. It is explained how to veneer the face of the door to match the edges and when a piece of veneer is not wide enough to cover a surface, how a joint must be made.

group_siblings.title: Union is strength: the story of plywood
group_siblings.creator_credit: K. Baron Hartley and Brent Productions

results.title: Cross currents
results.brief_description:
An image from a newspaper featuring Eastern European women being forced into prostitution and slavery at the end of the Yugoslav-Serbo-Croatian war, sets the scene for the Cross Currents exhibition. Presented in two sections, interactive video and linear video, as well as being in English and German language, events are recreated leading up to a police raid on a sex slave hotel in Berlin. The raid is recreated from the opposing points of view of an enslaved Croatian sex worker and her Serbian bodyguard.

Cross Currents premiered at ZKM, Centre for Art and Media, Karlsruhe, Germany in 1999.

results.title: Crofter boy
results.creator_credit: Stanley Russell and Thames and Clyde Film Company
results.brief_description: The life, education and activities of crofter children against the impressive background of the Scottish highlands. Shows how the coming of electricity to the crofters’ homes, the development of local industries and the mechanisation of agriculture, are gradually changing the traditional pattern of life. Local school-children at Gairloch and Poolwe in Western Ross appear in the film, with Kenneth Mackenzie, a crofter’s son, as the main character. Commentary by James McKechnie.
